Address.college_name: Dominican School of Philosophy and Theology

GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1932

Founded in 1890, the Dominican University of California is an independent university, distinguished by its history, geographic location, student profile, and educational philosophy. Our mission is to educate and prepare students to be ethical leaders and socially responsible global citizens who incorporate the Dominican values of study, reflection, community, and service into their lives. Located in Marin County, only 12 miles north of the Golden Gate Bridge, Dominican offers more than 60 undergraduate and graduate programs of study with an educational approach designed to serve our diverse student body. 

We provide students with a rigorous core curriculum while offering strong professional programs in the health sciences, business, and education. Our nationally recognized signature program, the Dominican Experience, allows undergraduate students to work with a coach, complete signature work, build a digital portfolio, and engage with the community. In 2020, Dominican was named the nation’s most transformative four-year university by the American Council on Education (ACE) in recognition of a deep commitment to student opportunity and success. 

Dominican sponsors 11 National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division II sports and is a member of the PacWest Conference, the largest conference in the NCAA Division II West Region. Engaged Learning — a hallmark of a Dominican education — incorporates active, collaborative learning in the classroom with enriching educational experiences beyond the classroom. Students apply academic skills and critical thinking to address societal issues, working in partnership with more than 30 community organizations. The Dominican/LINES Ballet BFA in Dance program, offered in partnership with Alonzo King LINES Ballet School, combines Dominican's comprehensive liberal arts education with technically rigorous and artistically expansive dance training. Dominican offers a research-intensive curriculum for undergraduate science education. 

Professors train students to work independently on specific research topics early in their freshman year, providing a unique experience and contributing to the success of faculty research programs. Each year, students from all disciplines present their original research at regional and national academic conferences. Students conduct research in many areas, including malaria, cancer, coral reefs, ecosystem health, marine wildlife, ecology, sudden oak death (SOD), sensory integration, autism, healthy aging, emergency room use during the Covid pandemic, access to healthcare in low-income communities, among other topics. Student research is shared worldwide via Dominican Scholar, the university's online research repository.
AdmissionRequirements: Graduation from high school or equivalent, and College Board SAT or ACT examination
TOEFL test for foreign students

AdmissionRequirements:
Undergraduate certificate or degree: either evidence of an earned high school diploma, General Educational Development (GED) test, or the successful completion of 12 semester units earned at an appropriately accredited postsecondary institution or foreign equivalent;
Master degree: an earned bachelor degree in a related major or discipline
Other disciplines may be acceptable and shall be reviewed on a case-by-case basis, and they may require prerequisite courses
All degrees must be earned at an appropriately accredited institution or foreign equivalent

IAU understands the differing rigor of institutions and grading scales around the world, and IAU evaluates prior academic credentials within their own context;
Doctoral degree: an earned bachelor and master degree
At least one degree must be in a related major or discipline

Other disciplines may be acceptable and shall be reviewed on a
case-by-case basis, and they may require prerequisite courses
All degrees must be earned at an appropriately accredited institution or foreign equivalent

IAU understands the differing rigor of schools and grading scales around the world, and IAU evaluates prior academic credentials within their own context

GeneralInformation.History: Created 1969

Westcliff University was established in 1993 to provide quality education for students wishing to enter the expanding fields of Business, Education, Law, Technology, and Engineering. We offer full-time working students a chance to take courses onsite at our beautiful California and Florida campuses and live online. All programs at Westcliff are convenient, flexible, and affordable.

Our graduate and undergraduate certificates and degree programs prepare students for immediate entry and advancement in their respective industries. While some schools only teach theoretical concepts, the programs at Westcliff University prepare students for the practical and theoretical elements required in the job market today. We prepare students for personal, professional, and academic success with innovative, up-to-date, and high-quality programs. The University has guidance and expertise from its Faculty, Program Advisory Council, and Board of Trustees that includes key leaders from local, national, international businesses and Fortune 500 organizations.

Westcliff is approved by the Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education (www.bppe.ca.gov) and is accredited by Senior College and University Commission (WSCUC) (www.wscuc.org), as well as programmatic accreditations for our College of Business by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP) (https://acbsp.org/) and Western State College of Law is accredited by the American Bar Association (ABA) (www.americanbar.org/).
AdmissionRequirements: High School Diploma or GED (or equivalent);
